Description: India-based shipping company Accord Ship Management pleaded guilty in connection with the illegal dumping of oily sludge, bilge wastes, and oil contaminated ballast water from one of the company's ships, the M/V Sportsqueen.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Company: Agrium US Inc. and Royster-Clark Inc
Recap of Ownership Changes: Nutrien was formed through the merger of Agrium and PotashCorp in 2018
Description: To settle a Clean Air Act case, a nitric acid production facility agreed to pay $750,000 in civil penalties and install state-of-the-art pollution control equipment at the facility.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Italian shipping company B.Navi Ship Management Services was sentenced to pay $1,500,000--a $1.2 million criminal fine and a $300,000 community service payment--and to serve three years of probation in connection with the illegal dumping of oily sludge, bilge wastes, and oil-contaminated ballast water from the M/V Windsor Castle, a 27,000 gross-ton bulk carrier vessel.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Carbofin S.p.A., an Italian domiciled company that owned and operated the M/T Marigola was sentenced to pay an overall criminal penalty of $2.75 million by the Honorable Virginia M. Hernandez Covington for knowingly falsifying the vessel's oil record book in violation of the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships, announced the Department of Justice Environment and Natural Resources Division and the U.S. Attorneys Office for the Middle District of Florida.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Cardiff Marine Inc, a Liberian-registered shipping company, was sentenced in federal court in Baltimore after pleading guilty to a felony violation of the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships. The company admitted falsifying records of illegal discharges of oily waste from the M/V Capitola, making false statements to the Coast Guard and other acts of concealment. U.S. District Judge Marvin J. Garbis sentenced Cardiff to pay a $2.4 million fine and serve three years probation, subject to an environmental compliance plan that includes audits by an independent third party auditor.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Company: Chian Spirit Maritime Enterprises, Inc. and Venetico Marine
Description: Greek-based shipping companies Chian Spirit Maritime Enterprises, Inc. and Venetico Marine each pleaded guilty to a felony violation related to the operation of the M/V Irene E.M., a large bulk carrier. Chian Spirit, the carrier owner, and Venetico, the carrier operator, admitted to violating the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS) by misleading U.S. Coast Guard investigators during the vessel's port call to the United States in December 2005. The companies were sentenced by the Court to pay a total criminal penalty of $1.25 million dollars and to implement a detailed, court-monitored Environmental Compliance Plan. A portion of the penalty amount ($250,000) was to be dedicated to a marine-based environmental enhancement community service project.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Company: Columbia Shipmanagement (Deutschland) GmbH  and Columbia Shipmanagement Ltd.
Description: Two shipping firms based in Germany and Cyprus were sentenced in federal court in Newark, N.J., to pay a $10.4 million penalty for felony obstruction of justice charges and violating the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships related to the deliberate concealment of vessel pollution from four ships that visited ports in New Jersey, Delaware and Northern California, the U.S. Attorney's Offices in New Jersey and Delaware, the U.S. Department of Justice Environment and Natural Resources Division and the U.S. Coast Guard announced.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Consultores de Navegacion, a Spanish company that operated the M/T Nautilus, an ocean-going chemical tanker ship, was sentenced to pay a fine of more than $2 million and serve three years of probation for criminal violations related to the overboard discharge of oil-contaminated bilge waste on the high seas.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Corpus Christi Day Cruise, Ltd., operator of the M/V Texas Treasure, pleaded guilty to obstructing a U.S. Coast Guard investigation into whether the ship had illegally discharged waste oil and deliberately bypassed its pollution prevention equipment. The company agreed to pay a penalty of $300,000.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Danish shipping company D/S Progress was sentenced to pay a $250,000 criminal fine for conspiring to conceal a hazardous leak in the hull of an oil tanker that visited Baltimore, for failing to report emergency discharges to save the ship and for presenting false log books to the U.S. Coast Guard in order to disguise the leak, emergency discharges and other deliberate acts of dumping oil.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: A Liberian-incorporated shipping company pleaded guilty in federal court in Trenton, N.J., to failing to keep accurate oily water discharge records and using falsified records to conceal the discharge at sea of untreated bilge from one of its cargo ships.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Company: Egyptian Tanker Company and Thome Ship Management
Description: Two shipping companies based in Egypt and Singapore pleaded guilty in federal court in Beaumont, Texas, to violating the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships and obstruction of justice for covering up the illegal dumping of oil-contaminated bilge water and garbage from one of their ships into the sea.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Epps Shipping Company, a Liberian corporation doing business out of Carolina, Puerto Rico, was sentenced in federal court for violating the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS) and making false statements to U.S. Coast Guard inspectors, announced Assistant Attorney General Ignacia S. Moreno and United States Attorney Rosa Emilia Rodriguez-Velez. The company was sentenced to pay a $700,000 criminal penalty to include a $100,000 payment towards community service projects to rehabilitate and protect coral reefs in Guanica Bay, Puerto Rico.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Fleet Management Ltd., a Hong Kong-based ship management firm, pleaded guilty to a criminal violation of the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 for its role in negligently causing the discharge of more than 50,000 gallons of fuel oil into San Francisco Bay from the Cosco Busan when the vessel struck the San Francisco Bay Bridge in dense fog on Nov. 7, 2007. Fleet Management also pleaded guilty to felony obstruction of justice and false statement charges for creating false and forged documents after the crash at the direction of shore-based supervisors with an intent to deceive the U.S. Coast Guard.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: France Shipmanagement agreed to pay $1.5 million to resolve allegations relating to a 40,000-gallon oil spill into the Delware Bay off the coast of New Jersey.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: A federal judge sentenced General Maritime Management (Portugal), the operator of a fleet of tanker vessels, and two crewmembers of the motor tanker Genmar Defiance for making false statements to the U.S. Coast Guard and failing to maintain an accurate Oil Record Book designed to prevent pollution of the world's oceans as required by United States and international law.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Company: Hiong Guan Navegacion Japan Co. Ltd.
Description: A federal judge sentenced the Japanese corporation Hiong Guan Navegacion Japan Co. Ltd., operator of the commercial cargo ship M/V Balsa-62, to three years probation and $1.75 million in penalties for conspiring to falsify and falsifying environmental compliance records.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Holy House Shipping AB, a Swedish corporation, was sentenced to pay a $1 million fine, a special assessment of $400,000 in community service payments and serve three years of probation for failing to maintain an accurate oil record book in an attempt to conceal illegal discharges of oil-contaminated waste directly into the ocean from one of its ships.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: IMC Shipping Co. Pte. Ltd., a Singapore corporation, pleaded guilty in federal court in Alaska to a three-count information alleging two violations of the Refuse Act for the illegal discharge of oil and soy beans and one violation of the Migratory Bird Treaty Act for killing of thousands of migratory birds that resulted from the grounding of the M/V Selendang Ayu on Dec. 8, 2004 in the Alaska Maritime National Wildlife Refuge.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Repeat offender, Ionia Management, a Greek company that manages a fleet of tanker vessels, was sentenced for its role in falsifying records to conceal the overboard dumping of waste oil from the M/T Kriton into international waters and its efforts to impede the investigation of the U.S. Coast Guard.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Karlog Shipping Company Ltd., operator of a fleet of cargo freighters based in Piraeus, Greece, pleaded guilty to making false statements and obstructing justice in connection with the overboard discharge of waste oil and was ordered to pay a penalty of $1 million.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Kirby Inland Marine L.P. agreed to pay $4.9 million in Clean Water Act civil penalties and to implement fleet-wide operational improvements to settle claims stemming from a 4,000-barrel (168,000-gallon) oil spill in the Houston Ship Channel in March 2014.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Martex Farms, a Puerto Rico company, was prdered to pay $92,620 for violating the worker protection provisions of U.S. pesticide laws.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: MSC Ship Management (Hong Kong) Limited--a Hong Kong-based container ship company--pleaded guilty and was sentenced to pay a $10 million criminal fine after admitting to engaging in conspiracy, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, false statements and violating the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: National Navigation Company pleaded guilty and was sentenced in U.S. District Court for the District of Oregon for 15 felony charges. The company, based in Cairo, Egypt, admitted to violating the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships and making false statements to federal officials.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Company: Nimmrich & Prahm Bereederung and Nimmrich & Prahm Reedrei
Description: Two German shipping companies pleaded guilty in federal court in Houston to criminal charges that they concealed the illegal dumping of oil at sea from U.S. Coast Guard inspectors. Nimmrich & Prahm Bereederung and Nimmrich & Prahm Reedrei, the operator and owner of the commercial cargo vessel M/V Susan K, will pay a $1.2 million dollar criminal penalty, $200,000 of which will go to the National Marine Sanctuaries Fund as a community service payment for projects aimed at preserving and restoring the Flower Garden Banks National Marine Sanctuary located off the Texas coast.  As a condition of probation, all vessels owned or operated by the defendants will be prohibited from entering U.S. ports or waters for five years.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: A ship management company headquartered in Greece that operated a 29,414 -ton cargo ship that made calls in multiple ports in Texas pleaded guilty and was sentenced late yesterday in federal court in Corpus Christi for deliberately concealing pollution discharges from the ship directly into the sea and for failing to notify the U. S. Coast Guard of numerous safety hazards on board the vessel. Noka Shipping Company Ltd., the operator of the M/V Florin, pleaded guilty to a violation of the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships for failing to properly maintain an oil record book as required by federal and international law, as well as, a violation of the Ports and Waterways Safety Act, for failing to report a hazardous condition on board to include excessive amounts of oil in the vessel's machinery spaces and bilges, excessive oil leaks on the vessel's main engine and generators, an authorized oil drainage system for the engine room and oil in the vessels fire suppression system. The company was sentenced to pay a $750,000 criminal fine along with a $150,000 community service payment to the congressionally-established National Marine Sanctuary Foundation.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Norbulk Shipping UK Ltd, a company based in Glasgow, United Kingdom, and operator of the M/V Murcia Carrier, pleaded guilty to failing to maintain an accurate oil record book in violation of the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS) and providing false statements to the U.S. Coast Guard concerning the vessels garbage record book. The company was sentenced to pay a criminal penalty of $750,000 and placed on three years of probation.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Singapore-based ODFJELL ASIA II PTE LTD (ODFJELL) and one of its senior crew members pleaded guilty yesterday in federal court in Hartford, Conn., for violating the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS), announced Acting Assistant Attorney General for the Justice Department's Environment and Natural Resources Division Robert G. Dreher, United States Attorney Deirdre M. Daly and Rear Admiral Daniel B. Abel, Commander of the First Coast Guard District in Boston. A quarter of the $1.2 million monetary penalty will fund improvements and protection of the Long Island Sound.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: A Louisiana ship-operating company was sentenced in U.S. District Court in New Orleans on charges related to the illegal discharge of oil into the oceans. Offshore Vessels LLC (OSV) was sentenced to pay a criminal fine of $1,750,000 and remit a payment of $350,000 as community service to the National Marine Sanctuary Foundation.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: A Connecticut-based shipping company pleaded guilty to charges of preparing false documents in an effort to cover up the illegal dumping of thousands of gallons of waste oil and sludge at sea. The company also agreed to pay a $4.2 million fine and serve three years of probation.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Overseas Shipholding Group Inc. agreed to pay a $37 million criminal penalty and plead guilty to 33 felony counts related to deliberate vessel pollution from nine ships and false pollution log entries in three additional ships, in six U.S. ports around the nation.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: PACCSHIP, the operator and manager of approximately ten ships carrying goods between Asia and ports in the United States, pleaded guilty and was sentenced to pay a $1.7 million fine for crimes related to improper transfers and discharges of oil-contaminated waste from two of its ships.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department
U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: American-based ship operator Pacific-Gulf Marine, Inc. was sentenced to a $1 million criminal fine, $500,000 for community service and three years of probation for deliberate acts of pollution involving a fleet of four ships, in violation of the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Pacific International Lines, a Singapore-based container ship company, was sentenced in D.C. federal court under the terms of a plea agreement that required the company to pay $2.2 million in criminal penalties. Pacific International Lines previously pleaded guilty to three felony charges that it made false statements to the U.S. Coast Guard and violated the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships by concealing illegal waste water operations and discharges in a falsified oil record book - a required log in which all overboard discharges must be recorded - and operating a vessel in waters of the United States without a functioning oil water separator (a required pollution control device).
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: A federal district court in Maine sentenced Petraia Maritime Ltd. to pay a fine of $525,000 and serve two years probation for violating the Act to Prevent Pollution From Ships.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Polembros Shipping LTD., a ship management company headquartered in Greece, was sentenced in federal court in New Orleans to pay a $2.7 million criminal fine for violating anti-pollution laws, ship safety laws, and making false statements during a U.S. Coast Guard investigation of the M/V Theotokos.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Princess Cruise Lines Ltd. agreed to pay a $40 million penalty and plead guilty to seven felony charges stemming from the deliberate dumping of oil-contaminated waste from the Caribbean Princess cruise ship.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: An Iowa-based shipping company that transported grain cargoes and petroleum products in the United States and abroad was sentenced to pay $2 million for illegally dumping thousands of gallons of waste oil, hundreds of tons of diesel-contaminated grain, and plastic wastes at sea.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: A New Zealand fishing company that owned and operated the tuna fishing vessel San Nikunau, and a former chief engineer on the ship, were sentenced in federal court for environmental crimes and obstruction of justice. Sanford Ltd. was ordered to pay a criminal fine of $1.9 million and pay $500,000 in community service to the National Marine Sanctuaries Foundation for the benefit of the Fagatele Bay National Marine Sanctuary in American Samoa.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: A federal judge sentenced the Korean corporation STX Pan Ocean Co. Ltd., operator of the commercial cargo ship M/V Ocean Jade, to pay $2.2 million in penalties and serve four years of probation for conspiring to falsify and falsifying environmental compliance records.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: A Panamanian company that operated a 40,000-ton oil tanker ship that regularly made calls in multiple ports in Texas pleaded guilty in federal court in Houston for deliberately concealing pollution discharges from the ship directly into the sea. The company has agreed to pay a $1 million criminal fine along with a $250,000 community service payment to the congressionally-established National Marine Sanctuary Foundation.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: The Sun Ace Shipping Company, based in Seoul, South Korea, was sentenced to pay a $400,000 penalty, a $100,000 community service payment to the National Fish and Wildlife Program, and a three-year term of probation during which its vessels will be banned from U.S. ports and waters.  Sun Ace had pleaded guilty to a one-count information for violating the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Uniteam Marine Shipping GmbH, a German corporation, was sentenced in federal court in San Juan, Puerto Rico, for violating the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS) and making false statements to the U.S. Coast Guard, announced Assistant Attorney General Ignacia S. Moreno and U.S. Attorney Rosa Emilia Rodriguez-Velez. The company was sentenced to pay an $800,000 criminal penalty, to include a $200,000 payment to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation to fund a community service project in the District of Puerto Rico.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Company: W. Bockstiegel Reederei GmbH  & Co. KG
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: A fishing vessel company that operated in and around American Samoa was convicted and sentenced for maintaining false and incomplete records relating to the discharge of oil and garbage.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Company: MST Mineralien Schiffahrt Spedition und Transport GmbH
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Bernhard Schulte Shipmanagement (Singapore) PTE LTD. (Bernhard), a vessel operating company, pleaded guilty in federal court to one count of maintaining false and incomplete records relating to the discharge of bilge waste from the tank vessel Topaz Express, a felony violation of the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: San Diego-based JM Fisheries LLC, G.S. Fisheries Inc., the companies' manager, and the chief engineer of the commercial fishing vessel agreed to pay a total of $725,000 in civil penalties to settle federal Clean Water Act claims related to oil pollution violations on the vessel. The companies and their manager also agreed to perform corrective measures to prevent future Clean Water Act violations.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Taylor Energy Company LLC, a Louisiana oil and gas company, agreed to pay a $43 million penalty and turn over all its remaining assets to the United States upon liquidation to resolve its liability for the oil spill at its former Gulf of Mexico offshore oil production facility, the source of the longest-running oil spill in U.S. history, ongoing since 2004.
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: Princess Cruise Lines Ltd. pleaded guilty to a second violation of probation imposed as a result of its 2017 criminal conviction for environmental crimes because it failed to establish and maintain an independent internal investigative office. Under the terms of a plea agreement, Princess was ordered to pay an additional $1 million criminal fine and required to undertake remedial measures to ensure that it and its parent Carnival Cruise Lines establish and maintain the independent internal investigative office known as the Incident Analysis Group (IAG).
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department

Description: ocean dumping
Agency: U.S. Coast Guard referral to the Justice Department
